messages.text:

```julia> [ CartesianIndex(i,j,k) for i in -1:1, j in -1:1, k in -1:1 if !iszero(CartesianIndex(i,j,k)) ]
26-element Array{CartesianIndex{3},1}:```

elements.text: 3 dimensions you said?

26-element Array{CartesianIndex{3},1}:

 CartesianIndex(4, 5, 6)```

messages.text:
I am getting something really weird with `Matrix(sparse())`
I have a vector X, which I rearrange into a Matrix using `Matrix(sparse())`
size makes sense: 40*40 = 1600
most numbers of the matrix are what I expect, but a column is completely off, see how the maximum are different, which is weird since it's supposed to be the same data, just rearranged from vector to matrix?
```julia> size(X)
(1600,)

julia> Z = Matrix(sparse(x, y, X));

julia> size(Z)
(40, 40)

julia> maximum(X)
10.062613798887448

julia> maximum(Z)
19.08816683600714```

I am unable to index into a 3-dimensional array with multiple cartesian indices:
```julia> A = rand(Int8, 3, 3, 3);

julia> A[CartesianIndex[CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1), CartesianIndex(3, 3, 3)]]
ERROR: ArgumentError: unable to check bounds for indices of type CartesianIndex{3}```
However this works when I remove the `CartesianIndex` type from the array:
```julia> A[[CartesianIndex(1, 1, 1), CartesianIndex(3, 3, 3)]]
2-element Array{Int8,1}:
 44
  2```
Any idea why this is?

messages.text:
hi all. I wanted to understand the scaling performance of multithreading. Say I have a function which calculate the root of a function repeatedly:
```using Base.Threads, Roots, BenchmarkTools

nthreads()
# 16

function singlethread()
    for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end

@btime singlethread()
# 411.331 ms (2200000 allocations: 210.57 MiB)

function multithreads()
    @threads for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end
@btime multithreads()
# 68.632 ms (2200081 allocations: 210.58 MiB)```
So even though I’m using 16 threads, the scaling is only 5 times. Is this a normal behavior? If so, any chance I can improve the scaling like switching to `@spawn` or multiprocessing?

elements.text: hi all. I wanted to understand the scaling performance of multithreading. Say I have a function which calculate the root of a function repeatedly:

using Base.Threads, Roots, BenchmarkTools

nthreads()
# 16

function singlethread()
    for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end

@btime singlethread()
# 411.331 ms (2200000 allocations: 210.57 MiB)

function multithreads()
    @threads for i in 1:100000
        find_zero(x -> x^3 - x^2, 5.0)
    end
end
@btime multithreads()
# 68.632 ms (2200081 allocations: 210.58 MiB)
So even though I’m using 16 threads, the scaling is only 5 times. Is this a normal behavior? If so, any chance I can improve the scaling like switching to
@spawn
or multiprocessing?

Is there a way to make my own types that have a variable number of arguments, similar to `Tuple{Int}, Tuple{Int,Int}, Tuple{Int,Int,Int}, ...` ? Like I want with one type definition for `Foo` to be able to do `Foo{Int}, Foo{Int, Int}, Foo{Int,Int,Int}, ...` .

messages.text:
The saga of my cheminformatic simulation continues!  The whole program now runs and no longer produces too many products, but now it produces too few.  I think the problem remains my model of the reaction of particles itself because I had to hack it together and still don’t understand how or why it works.

```for (location, reagents) in collision_locations(reagent_location_dictionary))
    while(length(reagents) > 1)
        deleteat!(
            reagent_location_dictionary[location], ((findfirst(==(reagents[1]), reagent_location_dictionary[location]), (findfirst(==(reagents[2])), reagent_location_dictionary[location])))

        if haskey(product_location_dictionary, location)
            push!(product_location_dictionary[location], length(product_location_dictionary) + 1)
        else
            product_location_dictionary[location] = [length(product_location_dictionary) + 1)]
```

I think the problem remains my model of the reaction of particles itself because I had to hack it together and still don’t understand how or why it works.

messages.text:
If all functions in a Julia program are type stable, then the methods which should be called can be determined during compile time and no dispatch during runtime is necessary, correct?
In this case dynamic dispatch and function overloading are equivalent?
Is there a way in Julia to emit a warning when not all functions are type stable?

is anyone else not being able to do surface plots using the PlotlyJS backend? works with regular plotly, but I need interactivity for this.
```x = collect(Float16, range(-2,length=100,stop=2))
y = collect(Float16, range(sqrt(2),length=100, stop=2))
z = (x.*y).-y.-x.+1
# a = plot(x,y,z, st = :surface)
surface(x,y,z)```
here's a picture of how the graph ends up with PlotlyJS and Plotly
